rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Cavitation phenomena and flow in diverging tubes
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The first part of this thesis is devoted to a general description and a discussion of the results of a series of experiments carried out by the author and Mr. L. O. Cooper in the Hydraulic Laboratories of McGill University. When a new hydraulic turbine or one of unusual proportions is being developed, the present day practice is to build a model of the turbine for operation in a testing flume, and to use the results from this to design the fullsized unit. It has been noticed that tests performed on large turbines built homologous with existing models generally show higher efficienaies than those obtained with the models. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hydraulics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The psychology of evidence
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Hermann Ebbinghaus once made the remark that psychology has a long past, but only a short history. Yet if one so construes this short history to include the period of the last half century or so, one finds that it has seen changes which, if they seem at first sight to have been trifling, have been none the less significant and meaningful. On casting around for evidence of this fact one still meets, it is true, with much of the older terminology borrowed from philosophy, and a few of the older and more well-tried concepts. The expression 'mind' is still in use, and the mind-body controversy is not settled once and for all, but the difference, to take an example, between Sir William Hamilton's Lectures and the latest copy of the Journal of Experimental Psychology is a striking one. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Psychology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The kinetics of chemical change in gaseous systems
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The kinetics of a chemical reaction can be best studied by observations of the rates of reaction, and the influence of temperature and pressure on these rates. Of the these states of aggregation - solid, liquid, and gaseous, the latter is the easiest to study because the kinetic theory applies to it best. The ordinary chemical equations by which reactions are usually represented show the initial and final conditions only. They do not give an indication of the actual mechanism and therefore of the number of molcules participating in thereaction. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Characteristics and abilities of evening high schoolstudents
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Adult education, as usually conceived, in the form of popular lectures, industrial classes, and Short leisure-time courses in cultural or vocational subjects for people of postschool age, has been widely studied by educators, psychologists, sociologists, theologians and even legislators, for many years. Comparatively little attention, however, has been paid to the most recent phase of the movement which would extend to evening students, not a supplementary type of elementary education, not an evening vocational or trade course, not a popularized form of cultural training, but a fully balanced secondary education equivalent to that offered in the public day high schools, adapted to the capacities, interests and needs of older students, and leading, if desired, to higher education and the professional school. Owing its origin both to the general adult education movement and to the part-time day continuation school for young workers in Europe and America, the evening secondary school is entirely a twentieth century educational phenomenon. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Psychology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The investigation of slime settling in Dorr thickeners
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] Slime settling is a process of dewatering in which flnely divided rock or ore material, with more or less colloidal matter, is separated in part from the solution in which it is suspended. The process is carried out in tanks or trays of various types and designs, but the apparatus preeminently in use for this purpose is the Dorr thickener. Slime settling fulfills a very important function in the mining industry. In the cyanide process for the recovery of gold and silver, most of the valuable solution is recovered by settling the leached ore and rock material in thickeners. In the flotation practice for the recovery of noble and base metals, concentrates are dewatered by thickening previous to filtering. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mining Engineering

rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Economics and Political Science
rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The manufacture and marketing of knitted goods in Canada
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Historical records and discoveries by antiquarians prove that everywhere in all ages, human beings have attempted to decorate themselves with fibrous materials of some sort. The development of industrial knowledge may be traced fram early periods in the history of civilization, when fabrics were made by plaiting grasses and felting wool. Some writers claim that knitting cannot boast of the long ancestry possessed by spinning and weaving, while others insist that knitting is probably the oldest form of fabrication, since it is on the order of the netting used for fishing among primitive tribes. It is impossible to state definitely whether certain classical references allude to knitting, as the ancient writerswould regard this as a type of weaving. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Knit goods industry -- Canada
Economics & Political Science

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Kinetics of gas reactions : a modified flow method for measuring reaction velocities
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Investigations of reaction velocities are of very considerable importance. The work performed up to the present has largely been a study of the kinetics of gaseous systems, which are to be preferred on account of their simplicity, and this phase of the investigations will be very materially assisted by the development of new experimental methods. It is to the advantage of the research worker that he shall have the choice of as many methods as possible in the attack on any problem, both from the point of view of checking results, and to assist him in investigating reactions hitherto impossible of study. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: La representation de la guerre de 1914-1918 et sesconsequences directes par le theatre francais
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Le théâtre français traversait à la veille de la guerre une période de pauvreté relative. La production était pourtant abondante, mais lea sujets des pièces representées semblaientindiquer une certaine sterilité des imaginations. Depuis le grand mouvement du Théâtre Libre, qui était déjà dans les premières années du XX siècle un fait du passé, aucun grand renouvellement de l'inspiration ne s'était produit sur la scène française. Curel, Brieux, et Hervien avaient pendant un certain temps essayé d'imposer la "pièce à idées", avec d'ailleurs des fortunes diverses, malgré leur valeur dramatique incontestable. Ils n'avaient pas en tout cas déterminé un courant général. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Interchangeable parts : an examination and comparison of fixed and modular trombones
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: For most of the 20th century, trombonists have been limited to a few mass-produced instruments that, while generally of high quality, do not always fit each player or situation well. Players seeking to “fine-tune” their trombones often were forced to seek expensive and unpredictable custom modifications. Also, trombonists performing in widely different musical styles and performance settings often own a number of different instruments, each suitable for different situations (i.e. classical vs. jazz). Recently, a number of boutique trombone manufacturers have emerged, offering modular trombones as a solution to both problems. These instruments are designed with interchangeable bells, slides, valves, tuning slides, and leadpipes, which can quickly and easily be exchanged with other parts of different designs, materials, or both. This thesis examines a number of traditional (fixed) and modular trombones with two objectives. The first objective is to determine if certain combinations of modular trombones could be used to adequately emulate the sound and feel of the fixed trombones they are based on. The second objective is to examine ways in which the performer might use different modular parts to tailor their sound to their specific musical needs and aesthetic preferences. [...]

Pour la majeure partie du 20e siècle, les trombonistes ont été limité à un nombre restreint d'instruments, tous produits à la chaîne. Quoique généralement de haute qualité, ces instruments ne correspondaient pas toujours précisément à chaque musicien ou chaque situation. Les trombonistes qui désiraient avoir un trombone adapté à leurs besoins étaient forcé d'effectuer des modifications coûteuses et imprévisibles. Également, les trombonistes qui voulaient jouer dans des styles variés de musique ou dans des circonstances divergentes devaient posséder plusieurs instruments, chacun étant utilisé pour un style en particulier (ex. classique vs. jazz).Récemment, plusieurs fabricants de trombone ont fait leurs apparitions, offrant des trombones modulaires comme solution aux deux problèmes. Ces instruments sont construits avec des parties interchangeables comme la cloche, la coulisse, le barillet, les coulisses d'accords et la branche d'embouchure, qui peuvent être facilement échanger avec d'autres parties soient construits différemment, construit avec un matériel différent ou les deux combinés.Cette thèse examine quelques trombones traditionnels (fixe) et modulaire avec deux objectifs. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Music -- Acoustics and physics
Trombone
Academic theses

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Sponge iron : some conditions essential to its production
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis contains an account of the nature and uses of sponge iron, the conditions theoretica1ly necessary for its production and methods that have been proposed for its production. It also describes experiments made by the writer to obtain information regarding the conditions essential for the production of sponge iron by heating hematite and magnetite ore with charcoal, peat, lignite, bituminous coal, coke and anthracite. There was no attempt made to devise or test any process tor the commercial production of sponge iron. The purpose of the work was to obtain information which would be fundamental for the design of such a commercial process. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Metallurgical Engineering

rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Civil Engineering and Applied Mechanics
rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some investigations in reinforced contrete, experimental research on concrete columns with traverse and longitudinal reinforcement
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The thesis deals with experimental research on concrete oolumns reinforced with horizontal and vertical steel. The object was to find if the horizontal reinforcement actuallyraised the ultimate strength. The somewhat slow, yet manifest changes which have been apparent within comparatively recent years in the design and construction of reinforced concrete structures constitute one of the greatest advances in engineering of the present generation. To mention but two, there is the Kane System of construction whereby the concrete in beams is made to work in conjunction with structural steel. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Civil Engineering & Applied Mechanics
Reinforced concrete

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The question of sex-differentiation in education
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The question of sex differantiation in education resolves itself into two problems 1} whether men and women should receive the same type of education, 2) whether the two sexes should be educated together. The first question entailed a discussion of the ideas concerning women which have controlled their lives and their education, of sex-differences, of the necessary function of women in society and the bearing of each of these on education. It was concluded that the similar educaation of men and women was preferable in all respects to sex-differentiation. In treating the second question, the objections to co-education were first discussed. Most of them were shown to arise from prejudices against women, andto bave been proved groundless by experience in mixed sohools. Finally the advantages claimed for co-education by its advocates were presented. 1) A more satisfactory emotional adjustment of the boys and girls. 2) Improved moral tone of the school. 3 Completer education of personality. 4) Better basis for mutual understanding between the sexes. 5) Training of the sexes in co-operation. 6) Improvement in economic and sooial position of women.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Women -- Education
Education
Coeducation

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Chemical and physiological properties of crystallineoestrogenic hormones
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A crystalline oestrogenic hormone has been isolated from human placenta. This substance shows a melting point ot 274 c. (uncorrected). The carbon-hydrogen analysis gives carbon 74.8 per cent, hydrogen 8.8 per cent. The mixed melting point with theelol shows no lowering. The substance differs physiologically from previously isolated female sex hormones. It is relatively inactive on the adult ovariectomized albino rat. The dose required is 16y, as compared to 1.5y for theelol. It is however, effective on the immature intact rat, 21 days old, in a dose of 1.2y. This is the same as theelol. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Title [[The]] morphology of Halictus Lerouxi Lep
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This paper covers the external and part of the internal anatomy of Halictus lerouxi LeP., a small solitary bee found in large numbers in the fruit belt of Nova Sootia. The structures throughout are compared with those of the honey bee, and closely resemble them in most cases. The lacinia of the maxilla is apparently absent. The tentorium bears a pair of dorsal arms, and the anterior and posterior arms of the two sides are connected by a V-shaped lamella. The thorax consists of the usual three segments plus the first abdominal segment or propodeum. The abdomen consists of nine segments, including the propodeum. The genital segments are invaginated within the sixth and seventh. The reproductive and digestive systems closely resemble those of the honey bee in general structure. The testes have become fused on the median line. There are more glands present in connection with the digestive system than is the case in A mellifica. The central nervous system has only four abdominal ganglia.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Entomology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of the geology in the vicinity of Corporation Quarry, Mount Royal, Montreal, Canada
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Corporation Quarry is on the northern edge of the Mt. Royal intrusive plug. Three ages of intrusive rock, - essexite, syenitic breccia, and nepheline syenite, are represented here, as well as seven ages of dykes. The following geological sequence was observed in the Quarry; beginning with the oldest rocks:- 1. Trenton limestone.2. Essexite,- coarse grained, melanocratic, varying greatly in texture. Composed essentially of titaniferous augite, magnesiohastingsi te arnphi bole, calcic plagioclase ranging from An85 to An30, with accessory olivine, titanite, magnetite and apatite. 3. Alkalic lamprophyre dykes;- black, fine-grained, composed essentially of needles of magnesiohastingsite set in a ground mass of alkali feldspars. Their relation to the essexite is not very definite. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Standard of living studies and their significance : including a special study in Montreal
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This Thesis undertakes the study of the significance of standards of living among the wage-earning population and an analysis of how they have been measured. Part I deals with the concept "standard of living", its origin, and the development of interest in such studies during the last 250 years, and classifies studies on the basis of the underlying purpose and methods used. Part II shows the results of a study made by the writer relating to a specially selected group of unskilled workers in Montreal in 1931. Part III is a general comparison of the results of some inquiries in Britain, United States and Canada into the standard of living of wage-earners. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sociology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The microbiology of air-dried cultivated soils
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The beneficial effect of the drying of soils upon their fertility has been a recognised fact in agricultural practice for many centuries. Russell, (16., p.p. 343-344), points out that this effect has been brought about, either by the exposure of the soil to the baking heat of the sun -- as in India and in Egypt, (Prescott (15) ), or by deliberate burning ofthe soil. The increasing interest in soil science within recent years has stimulated investigation of this phenomenon from various viewpoints: evidence has accumulated to show that the beneficial effects of drying are due to changes in both the physical and the microbiological conditions of the soil. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bacteriology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Hormonal studies of the placenta and theanterior lobe of the pituitary body
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Investigations have been made in the McGill Biochemical Laboratory during the last three years on the endocrine functions of the ovary, placenta and anterior lobe of the pituitary, with the hope of bringing to light some of the relations that exist between them. Some of the results have already been published (29)(30)(39)(40)(41)(42) (43)(44) but much work is still in progress. As the work of this thesis has been largely confined to the anterior hypophysis and placenta, they alone will be discussed in detail and the ovary only in so far as it is related to these organs. The literature of this subject is enormous and new facts are being brought forth so rapidly that it is almost impossible to keep pace with them. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Generation and reception of ultra short radio waves
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The communication of intelligence between remote points on the earth's surface without the aid of connecting wires was developed from a fantastic dream in the minds of visionarytheorists and optimistic experimentalists into a practicable working possibility in the closing five years of the nineteenth century. Credit for the final developments madeat that time must go to Marconi, but his work was the culmination of a long series of investigations carried out by Clerk-Maxwell, Preece, He~.tz, Branly, Lodge, Tesla, Popoff, Righi, and many others, all of whom were responsible for theoretical or experimental advances wh'ich brought one step closer the goal finally reached by Marconi. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Electrical Engineering

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Preparation and physical properties of aliphatic acetylenes
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The work to be described in this thesis deals with the preparation and investigation of the physical properties of the lower members of an homologous series namely the alkyl acetylenes. In view of the fact that small differences in properties would be observed in the case of isomeric substances and also that the validity of the observations in the case of certain properties depends solely on the purity of the compound investigated new details have been developed in connection with the methods of preparation and special care devoted to the purification of the compounds. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Juvenile delinquency in Montreal
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Before dealing directly with the local problem of juvenile delinquency in Montreal, a brief historical account of the general subject is in order. Cure rather than prevention has frequently seemed to be the aim of man's research whether in the medical, religious, or social field. Not until comparatively recent years have men concerned themselves with causes. This has been only too true in the attitude of society towards those who oft transgress its rules. The amount of time, thought and money which the State has expended in punishing those who have committed crimes has been enormous throughout the centuries. Only within recent years have there been made any intelligent and organized effort to discover the reasons why the individual became a delinquent, and to ascertain the methods by which he may be brought into a harmonious relationship with society. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Juvenile delinquents -- Québec (Province) -- Montréal
Sociology
Juvenile delinquency -- Québec (Province) -- Montréal

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The penetration of aqueous sulphite solutions into spruce wood
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In 1927, Dr. John Campbell suggested to the Pulp and Paper Division of the Forest Products Laboratories of Canada that information of considerable value might be obtained by a study of the penetration of liquids into wood. This suggestion was incorporated into the research program of the Laboratories, and Dr. H. W. Johnston from 1927 to 1929 made a preliminaryinvestigation of the penetration of liquids into Jack Pine. The results obtained were of sufficient interest to warrant further study, and from 1930 to 1932 the field has been developed by five graduate students in Physical Chemistry at McGill University working under the direction of Dr. 0. Mass. This thesis describes one part of the work, that of thepenetration of aqueous sulphite solutions into spruce wood.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Migration between Canada and the United States : with particular reference to professional and intellectual classes
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis deals with the migration between Canada and the United States with particular reference to the professional and intellectual classes, or what might be called by some such popular phrase as the "Export of Brains". As far as I have been able to discover, there has been very little work previously done on this subject. As a resultt the material has been collected bit by bit by going through long lists of names and writing many individual letters. In the time at my disposal I have not been able to make a very complete investigation of the subject which would entail even more elaborate communication and research. It is the idea of the Department, however, that I present what material I have been able to find, not so much as a well rounded and complete thesis but as an introduction to the subject and a fragmentary collection of notes.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Canada -- Emigration and immigration
United States -- Emigration and immigration
Ecomonimcs

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Franklin and Canada
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The following pages deal with Benjamin Franklin's interest and part in the question of Canada as that question enters into the continental history of North America and the relations of North America with the British and French governments between the years 1745-1790. He p1ayed his part in both falls of Louisburg; Braddock's expedition; the taking of Quebec; England's choice of Canada over Guadeloupe; crushing Pontiac's Conspiracy; organizing the Canadian post-office; introducing the first Canadian printing presses; developing Nova Scotia; the American invasion of Canada; the Moravian missions in Labrador; improving Canada's New Brunswick boundary; and but for his colleagues Jay and Adams, he would have added Canada to the United States in 1783. In line with the proverbial variety of his interests the last forty-five years of his life represent an unbroken sequence of effort to make the allegiance of Canada and America one.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Canada -- History -- 1763-1791
Franklin, Benjamin, 1706-1790
History
Canada -- History -- To 1763 (New France)

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Flotation of gold and copper in Noranda ore
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The scope of the investigation may be briefly summarized as follows:- Investigation of the flotation characteristics of the ore including the effect of aeration, the value of the employment of cyanide, the compilation of data which would either support or refute an hypothesis regarding the effect in flotation of alkaline reagents; and finally the compilation of data to expl~in difficulties which developed in connection with the recovery of the gold in the ore. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mining Engineering
